title: Netflix's foray into ad-backed content was rushed and the pricing is too high compared with peers, analyst says; Benchmark says it's too early to fully assess the performance of the new ad-based tier
text:
The rapid launch was an apparent reaction to the momentum gathering in the ad-based market and issues Netflix is facing in boosting global member growth. That's despite some high-profile shows the streaming giant is currently enjoying, including the Addams Family remake "Wednesday," and the "Harry & Meghan" documentary, both of which have drawn record audiences

"Although there is a strong element of hubris in Netflix pricing advertising well above CPMs (cost per mile) for AVOD (advertising-based video on demand) rivals we do feel it is premature to write-off Netflix's $6.99 AVOD tier," Benchmark analyst Matthew Harrigan wrote in a note to clients.

See now: Netflix shares sink amid report of sluggish start for ad tier, but one analyst says that's no surprise

"It is too early to definitively assess fully relative cannibalization of fully priced SVOD (subscription-based video on demand) activity relative to advertising revenue benefits and incremental member growth," he wrote.

Benchmark is expecting the AVOD service to provide $21 to $45 in share value if executed well in a highly competitive market and slowing immediate ad market.

"We still expect Netflix to generate significant global growth, although the broader gamut of programming including sports supporting The Disney Bundle DIS and Amazon Prime AMZN is a disadvantage for Netflix despite its entrenched position as the scripted content volume leader," said the analyst.

See also: Netflix stock upgraded as one analyst sees 'more ways to win'

Data platform Antenna estimates that churn at Netflix rose to 3.5% in the third quarter from 3.4% in the second quarter, and a low 2.0% in 2021, at the height of the pandemic, said Harrigan. Year-to-date churn is estimated at 3.3%, which is up from 1.9% in 2021.

And Kantar Media found that AVOD migration from SVOD gathered steam in the third quarter, based on a survey of 11,435 U.S. video streaming customers, he wrote.

Benchmark is sticking with its sell rating on Netflix stock, but raised its price target to $225 from $162, while acknowledging that the prior target was "overly bearish."

The stock was flat Friday but has fallen 52% in the year to date, while the S&P 500 SPX has fallen 18%.

Netflix's foray into ad-backed content was rushed and the pricing is too high compared with peers, analyst says
